item.title: Exercise 2: Composing with Extended Techniques
item.dc:creator: pedro

item.title: Research Task 1: Clarity in Choir Writing
item.dc:creator: pedro
item.description: Thomas Tallis’s “If Ye Love Me” is a largely homophonic piece that conveys a smooth, contemplative, and peaceful mood. The voice leading is notably strong, with each part moving fluidly without large leaps—except for occasional...
item.content:encoded:
Thomas Tallis’s “If Ye Love Me” is a largely homophonic piece that conveys a smooth, contemplative, and peaceful mood. The voice leading is notably strong, with each part moving fluidly without large leaps—except for occasional moments in the bass, which add subtle grounding. The vocal ranges are narrow, helping maintain the calm atmosphere. Dynamics are used minimally, giving the piece a consistent, serene tone that emphasizes the message of the text.

W.A. Mozart’s “Ave Verum Corpus” introduces a bit more tension through dissonances at the beginning, distinguishing it from the pure harmony in Tallis’s work. Although primarily homophonic, Mozart allows the voices slightly more freedom, especially in melismatic passages, which brings an emotional richness to the piece. The dynamics, introduced at crucial moments, lend drama and depth, reinforcing the solemn reverence of the text and creating a powerful listening experience.

Clara Schumann’s “Abendfeier in Venedig” uses dynamics to create high and low points in the music, breaking away from a homogenous sound. It’s more homophonic than Mozart’s piece, with fewer dissonances, resulting in a calm and harmonious tone. Smooth voice leading, with no major leaps, keeps the mood gentle and reflective. Schumann’s approach to dynamics here gives the piece a flowing quality, guiding the listener through waves of subtle emotion.

Edward Elgar’s “Owls” takes a distinct approach, employing a question-and-answer texture that enhances the conversational tone. The word painting is evident, as in the word “fall,” where the music mirrors the meaning of the text. The absence of melismas contributes to a more straightforward, spoken quality, which, combined with frequent pauses, creates an air of mystery. This approach draws the listener into the contemplative, somewhat eerie atmosphere Elgar crafts.

Samuel Coleridge-Taylor’s “Summer is Gone” is marked by extreme dissonance, aligning with the theme of seasonal change and the melancholy of summer’s end. While the texture remains primarily homophonic, there are flourishes in the soprano part that add expressiveness. The use of melismas complements the piece’s reflective tone, enhancing the sense of nostalgia. This combination of dissonance, homophony, and occasional embellishments creates a poignant representation of the season’s passing.

Morten Lauridsen’s “O Magnum Mysterium” is predominantly homophonic, with a limited range for most voices except the soprano, which features notable leaps that embellish the melody. The melismas here are subtle yet significant, adding depth and reverence to the music. Lauridsen also employs divisi in the alto and bass parts, enriching the harmonic texture and adding a layer of complexity that elevates the spiritual nature of the piece.

James Macmillan’s “O Radiant Dawn” is highly homophonic, with all voices moving together in a unified manner. The standout moment comes in the word “come,” where the dynamics build progressively, creating a sense of anticipation and proximity. The narrow melodic lines place the focus on dynamic shifts rather than complex melodic expressivity, resulting in a straightforward yet powerful piece. This use of dynamics brings depth to Macmillan’s minimalistic, chant-like approach, aligning with the theme of yearning.

Cheryl Frances-Hoad’s “There is No Rose” offers an unusual take on the traditional Christmas carol. It begins simply with homophonic textures, but soon shifts to exotic harmonies that add an element of surprise and mystery. This harmonic shift breaks from the traditional carol sound, bringing an unexpected, almost sacred quality to the music. The juxtaposition of simplicity and complexity gives the piece a layered, dynamic character.

Arvo Pärt’s “Magnificat” is highly contemplative, achieved through homophony, gentle melismas, and a narrow vocal range. The dynamics remain mostly soft, reinforcing the meditative atmosphere, though occasional fortes bring a heightened intensity to specific moments. This delicate balance between restraint and emphasis contributes to a serene, reverent tone that is characteristic of Pärt’s minimalist style. The dynamics help sustain interest and guide the listener through the piece’s quiet depths.

item.title: Exercise 1: Composing for Choir
item.dc:creator: pedro

item.title: Research Task 2: Building a More Colourful Palette
item.dc:creator: pedro
item.description: Clapping Clapping involves striking the palms of the hands together to produce a sharp, percussive sound. The volume and resonance can be adjusted by varying the hand position or the force used. The sound is...
item.content:encoded:
Clapping

Clapping involves striking the palms of the hands together to produce a sharp, percussive sound. The volume and resonance can be adjusted by varying the hand position or the force used. The sound is rhythmic and sharp, often used to create a sense of unity or pulse in a piece. Clapping is typically notated with an “X” on the staff .

Overtone Singing

Overtone singing is produced by creating two or more pitches simultaneously using different parts of the vocal tract. The sound is unique and resonant creating droning effect with overtones that seem to shimmer above the fundamental. It can be notated specifying the overtone and fundamental on a separate staff line.

Whispered Singing

Whispered singing involves singing pitches with minimal vocal fold vibration, creating a breathy, almost ghostly sound. Unlike standard singing, whispered singing uses more air and less vocal tone, creating a soft, airy quality. It may be notated with specific text instructions, written as “whispered singing” above the vocal line.

Vocoder

A vocoder digitally alters the voice by combining vocal input with synthesised sound. The singer’s vocal pitch and inflection control the synthesised output, producing an electronic voice effect. The resulting sound is robotic. The use of a vocoder can be marked in the score with an instruction, specifying sections where the digital effect should be applied. I believe a reference to the type of sound effect or synth may also be included.

Stamping

Stamping involves forcefully pressing one’s foot onto the ground, creating a deep, rhythmic sound. It generates a thudding, resonant sound that can add primal energy and a grounding quality to a piece. It can be notated with an “X” accompanied by rhythmic notation.
